title: Language and Computing
content:
Turing Problem

Type-0-languages = Recursively Enumerable Languages = Semi-decidable Languages

Decidable languages = Recursive languages

  • if there is a Turing Machine that accepts it and always stop on any word

Context-sensitive languages(Type-1-languages): subset of recursive languages

  • These are grammars where the left-hand side of a production is always shorter than the right-hand side

Halt problem: the language of encodings of Turing machines that will always stop

There are languages that are accepted by a TM (i.e., type 0 languages) but that are undecidable

DFA

A deterministic finite automaton (DFA) A=(Q,Σ,δ,q0,F)A = (Q,Σ, δ, q_0, F)A=(Q,Σ,δ,q0​,F) is given by:

  1. A finite set of statesstatesstates QQQ
  2. A finite set of input symbols, the alphabet,Σalphabet, Σalphabet,Σ
  3. A transitiontransitiontransition functionfunctionfunction δ∈Q×Σ→Qδ \in Q \times Σ \rightarrow Qδ∈Q×Σ→Q
  4. An initialinitialinitial statestatestate q0∈Qq_0 \in Qq0​∈Q
  5. A set of finalfinalfinal statesstatesstates F⊆QF \sube QF⊆Q

The language of DFA

Using the extended transition function δ^\hat{\delta}δ^, we define the language L(A)L(A)L(A) of a DFA AAA formally:

  • δ^(q,ϵ)=q\hat{\delta}(q,\epsilon) = qδ^(q,ϵ)=q

  • δ^(q,xw)=δ^(δ(q,x),w)\hat{\delta} (q, xw) = \hat{\delta}(\delta(q,x),w)δ^(q,xw)=δ^(δ(q,x),w)

  • L(A)={w  ∣  δ^(q0,w)∈F}L(A) = \{w \;|\; \hat{δ}(q_0,w) \in F\}L(A)={w∣δ^(q0​,w)∈F}

NFA

A nondeterministic finite automaton (NFA) A=(Q,Σ,δ,S,F)A = (Q,Σ, δ, S, F)A=(Q,Σ,δ,S,F) is given by:

  1. A finite set of statesstatesstates QQQ,
  2. A finite set of input symbols, the alphabet,Σalphabet, Σalphabet,Σ
  3. A transitiontransitiontransition functionfunctionfunction δ∈Q×Σ→P(Q)δ \in Q \times Σ \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(Q)δ∈Q×Σ→P(Q),
  4. A set of initialinitialinitial statesstatesstates S⊆QS \sube QS⊆Q,
  5. A set of finalfinalfinal (or acceptingacceptingaccepting) states F⊆QF \sube QF⊆Q.
The language of NFA

δ^∈P(Q)×Σ∗→P(Q)\hat{δ} \in \mathcal{P}(Q)\timesΣ^∗ \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(Q)δ^∈P(Q)×Σ∗→P(Q), δ^(P,w)\hat{δ}(P,w)δ^(P,w) is set of states that are reachable from one of states in PPP on word www

  • δ^(P,ϵ)=P\hat{\delta}(P, \epsilon) = Pδ^(P,ϵ)=P
  • δ^(P,xw)=δ^(⋃{δ(q,x)  ∣  q∈P},w)\hat{\delta}(P, xw) = \hat{\delta}(\bigcup\{\delta(q,x)\;|\;q\in P\}, w)δ^(P,xw)=δ^(⋃{δ(q,x)∣q∈P},w)
  • L(A)={w  ∣  δ^(S,w)∩F≠∅}L(A) = \{w\;|\;\hat{\delta}(S,w)\cap F\not =\empty\}L(A)={w∣δ^(S,w)∩F=∅}

Context-free Grammar

A context-free grammar G=(N,T,P,S)G = (N, T, P, S)G=(N,T,P,S) is given by

  1. A finite set NNN of nonterminalnonterminalnonterminal symbolssymbolssymbols or nonterminalsnonterminalsnonterminals.
  2. A finite set TTT of terminalterminalterminal symbolssymbolssymbols or terminalsterminalsterminals.
  3. N∩T=∅N \cap T = \emptysetN∩T=∅; i.e., the sets NNN and TTT are disjoint.
  4. A finite set P⊆N×(N∪T)∗P \sube N \times(N \cup T)^∗P⊆N×(N∪T)∗ of productions. A production (A,α)(A, α)(A,α), where A∈NA \in NA∈N and α∈(N∪T)∗α \in (N \cup T)^∗α∈(N∪T)∗ is a sequence of nonterminal and terminal symbols. It is written as A→αA \rightarrow αA→α in the following.
  5. S∈NS\in NS∈N: the distinguished start symbol.

The language of a grammar

L(G)⊆T∗L(G) \sube T^∗L(G)⊆T∗, consists of all terminal sentential forms:

  • L(G)={w∈T∗  ∣  S⇒G∗w}L(G) = \{w\in T^*\;|\;S\xRightarrow[G]{*}w\}L(G)={w∈T∗∣S∗G​w}

Pushdown Automaton

A Pushdown Automaton P=(Q,Σ,Γ,δ,q0,Z0,F)P = (Q,Σ, Γ, δ, q_0,Z_0, F)P=(Q,Σ,Γ,δ,q0​,Z0​,F) is given by the following data

  1. A finite set QQQ of states,
  2. A finite set ΣΣΣ of input symbols (the alphabet),
  3. A finite set ΓΓΓ of stack symbols,A
  4. transition function
    δ∈Q×(Σ∪{ϵ})×Γ→Pfin(Q×Γ∗)δ \in Q \times (Σ \cup \{ϵ\}) \times Γ \rightarrow P_{fin}(Q \times Γ^∗)δ∈Q×(Σ∪{ϵ})×Γ→Pfin​(Q×Γ∗)
    Here Pfin(A)P_{fin}(A)Pfin​(A) are the finite subsets of a set; i.e., this can be defined as
    Pfin(A)={X∣X⊆A∧X is finite.}P_{fin}(A) = \{X | X \sube A \wedge X \text{ is finite.}\}Pfin​(A)={X∣X⊆A∧X is finite.}
    Thus, PDAs are in general nondeterministic because they may have a choice of transitions from any state. However, there are always only finitely many choices.
  5. An initial state q0∈Qq_0 \in Qq0​∈Q,
  6. An initial stack symbol Z0∈ΓZ_0 \in ΓZ0​∈Γ,
  7. A set of final states F⊆QF \sube QF⊆Q.

ID(Instantaneous Description)

Such a triple (q,w,γ)∈Q×Σ∗×Γ∗(q,w, γ) \in Q\timesΣ^∗\timesΓ^∗(q,w,γ)∈Q×Σ∗×Γ∗ is called an Instantaneous Description (ID)

Acceptance by final state

  • L(P)={w  ∣  (q0,w,Zo)⊢∗(q,ϵ,γ)∧q∈F}L(P) = \{w\;|\;(q_0,w,Z_o)\vdash^*(q,\epsilon,\gamma)\wedge q \in F\}L(P)={w∣(q0​,w,Zo​)⊢∗(q,ϵ,γ)∧q∈F}

Acceptance by empty stack

  • L(P)={w  ∣  (q0,w,Z0)⊢∗(q,ϵ,ϵ)}L(P)=\{w\;|\;(q_0,w,Z_0)\vdash^*(q,\epsilon, \epsilon)\}L(P)={w∣(q0​,w,Z0​)⊢∗(q,ϵ,ϵ)}

Deterministic PDAs

  • ∣δ(q,x,z)∣+∣δ(q,ϵ,z)∣≤1,q∈Q,x∈Σ,z∈Γ|\delta(q,x,z)| +|\delta(q,\epsilon,z)| \leq 1, q \in Q,x\in \Sigma,z\in \Gamma∣δ(q,x,z)∣+∣δ(q,ϵ,z)∣≤1,q∈Q,x∈Σ,z∈Γ

Turing Machine

A Turing Machine M=(Q,Σ,Γ,δ,q0,B,F)M = (Q,Σ, Γ, δ, q_0,B, F)M=(Q,Σ,Γ,δ,q0​,B,F) is:

  1. A finite set QQQ of states;
  2. A finite set ΣΣΣ of symbols (the alphabet);
  3. A finite set ΓΓΓ of tape symbols s.t. Σ⊆ΓΣ \sube ΓΣ⊆Γ. This is the case because we use the tape also for the input;
  4. A transition function
    δ∈Q×Γ→{stop}∪Q×Γ×{L,R}δ \in Q \times Γ \rightarrow \{stop\} \cup Q \times Γ \times \{L, R\}δ∈Q×Γ→{stop}∪Q×Γ×{L,R}
    The transition function defines how the machine behaves if is in state qqq and the symbol on the tape is xxx. If δ(q,x)δ(q, x)δ(q,x) = stop then the machine stops otherwise if δ(q,x)=(q′,y,d)δ(q, x) = (q′, y, d)δ(q,x)=(q′,y,d) the machines gets into state q′q′q′, writes yyy on the tape (replacing xxx) and moves left if d=Ld = Ld=L or right, if d=Rd = Rd=R;
  5. An initial state q0∈Qq_0 \in Qq0​∈Q;
  6. The blank symbol B∈ΓB \in ΓB∈Γ but B∉ΣB \not\in ΣB∈Σ. Initially, only a finite section of the tape containing the input is non-blank;
  7. A set of final states F⊆QF \sube QF⊆Q.

ID(Instantaneous Description)

An element (γL,q,γR)∈ID(γ_L, q, γ_R) \in ID(γL​,q,γR​)∈ID describes a situation where the TM is in state QQQ, the non-blank portion of the tape on the left of the head is γLγ_LγL​ and the non-blank portion of the tape on the right, including the square under the head, is γRγ_RγR​

The language of a Turing Machine

  • L(M)={w∈Σ∗  ∣  (ϵ,q0,w)⊢∗(γL,q′,γR)∧q′∈F}L(M) = \{w\in \Sigma^*\;|\;(\epsilon, q_0,w)\vdash^*(γ_L, q', γ_R)\wedge q' \in F\}L(M)={w∈Σ∗∣(ϵ,q0​,w)⊢∗(γL​,q′,γR​)∧q′∈F}

Predictive parsing

Consider productions for a nonterminal X

  • X→α  ∣  βX \rightarrow \alpha \;|\;\betaX→α∣β

Suppose it can be the case that

  • β⇒∗ϵ\beta \xRightarrow[]{*}\epsilonβ∗​ϵ

Disambiguating context-free grammars

  • E→E+E  ∣  E∗E  ∣  E↑E  ∣  (E)  ∣  NE \rightarrow E + E \;|\; E * E \;|\;E \uparrow E \;|\; (E) \;|\; NE→E+E∣E∗E∣E↑E∣(E)∣N
  • N→0  ∣  1  ∣  2N\rightarrow0\;|\;1\;|\;2N→0∣1∣2
  • $\uparrow(right) ;>;*(left);>;+(left) $

The subexpressions of expressions of the highest precedence

  • E→E1+E1  ∣  E1E\rightarrow E_1+E_1\;|\;E_1E→E1​+E1​∣E1​
  • E1→E2∗E2  ∣  E2E_1\rightarrow E_2*E_2\;|\;E_2E1​→E2​∗E2​∣E2​
  • E2→E3↑E3  ∣  E3E_2\rightarrow E_3 \uparrow E_3\;|\;E_3E2​→E3​↑E3​∣E3​
  • E3→(E)  ∣  NE_3\rightarrow (E)\;|\;NE3​→(E)∣N
  • N→0  ∣  1  ∣  2N\rightarrow 0\;|\;1\;|\;2N→0∣1∣2

Make the corresponding productions left- and right-recursive

  • E→E+E1  ∣  E1E\rightarrow E+E_1\;|\;E_1E→E+E1​∣E1​
  • E1→E1∗E2  ∣  E2E_1\rightarrow E_1*E_2\;|\;E_2E1​→E1​∗E2​∣E2​
  • E2→E3↑E2  ∣  E3E_2\rightarrow E_3 \uparrow E_2\;|\;E_3E2​→E3​↑E2​∣E3​
  • E3→(E)  ∣  NE_3\rightarrow (E)\;|\;NE3​→(E)∣N
  • N→0  ∣  1  ∣  2N\rightarrow 0\;|\;1\;|\;2N→0∣1∣2

Elimination of left recursion
